newsitem.title: USA: Fourteen children overdose at Masschusetts dance.
newsitem.headline: Fourteen children overdose at Masschusetts dance.

text.p: Fourteen children aged 12 to 17 were in Boston-area hospitals on Saturday after apparently overdosing on a muscle relaxant late on Friday at a dance, police said.
Ten of the victims, mostly girls, were in critical condition, many of them on life-support systems, according to hospital officials.

Police found some of the muscle relaxants, called baclosen, and an empty bottle at the "Teen Supreme" dance at the Boys and Girls Club in Woburn, Massachusetts, about 20 miles (32 km) north of Boston.
"They were passing out the pills and they just started falling," Woburn Police officer Paul Lucero told Reuters.
Police were investigating how the children got the drug, which one hospital official said is commonly used to treat multiple sclerosis.
Local reports said that the victims, mostly eighth grade girls from Kennedy Junior High School in Woburn, apparently ingested multiple doses of the drug shortly before going to the dance.
Seven boys and girls aged 12 to 17 were in serious condition and one was in good condition at Children's Hospital in Boston, spokeswoman Cindy Rovelle said.
Two girls were in serious condition and one girl was in stable condition at the Lahey Hitchcock Medical Centre in Burlington, north of Boston, spokeswoman Christine McDonald said.
"I believe the ones we have are around 14," McDonald said.
Two girls were in fair condition at Winchester Hospital, also located north of Boston, spokeswoman Deb Trask said. Their ages were not released.
One 13-year-old girl was in serious condition at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, a spokeswoman there said.
